title: Tuesday, 4th July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:02am

Well, things are happening!

PM11:03am

Let's start with the obv pic -- ignoring N Korea, Trump and so on

11:03 am
PM11:03am

PM11:03am

Best explanation for this -- from the right -- get's a prize

PM11:03am

Not sure what prize

11:03 am
PM11:04am

But we'll find something

PM11:04am

It was just those stocks

PM11:04am

No explanation from Nasdaq

11:05 am
PM11:05am

"Just a glitch" is unsatisfactory

BE11:05am

Really? I'm okay with it.

BE11:06am

Please use the sharing tools found via the email icon at the top of articles. Copying articles to share with others is a breach of FT.com T&Cs and Copyright Policy. Email licensing@ft.com to buy additional rights. Subscribers may share up to 10 or 20 articles per month using the gift article service. More information can be found at https://www.ft.com/tour.
https://www.ft.com...-91a7-502f7ee26895

Nasdaq indicated that the glitch was related to “unlisted trading privileges”, a right granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission that allows exchanges to facilitate trading of stocks listed on other official US exchanges as well.

11:05 am
BE11:06am

In its statement the exchange said: “Nasdaq is investigating the improper use of test data distributed by the UTP [unlisted trading privileges] and consumed by third parties. As part of its normal process, the UTP distributed test data and certain third parties improperly propagated the data. Nasdaq is working with third-party vendors to resolve the matter.”

PM11:06am

That means nothing whatsoever to me

BE11:07am

Well, complex computer systems go wrong a lot. The evidence of that is, literally, staring us in the face.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Not understanding the explanation is what makes it credible, quite frankly.

PM11:07am

Indeed

BE11:08am

Compare and contrast to the BA one about power centres.

11:08 am
PM11:08am

But why do we then think we are on the bring of a new data-driven era, with self driving cars and so on?

BE11:09am

Um .......... I'm not sure I go along with the argument that individual things fail so everything must fail. It feels a tad luddite.

BE11:09am

(@Pharma: best theory I've heard is 1+2 = 3, 3+4=7 )

11:10 am
BE11:10am

(Though the John Nash numerology has been fun as well.)

undefined
PM11:10am

So Worldpay!

11:10 am
PM11:10am

PM11:10am

PM11:11am

11:11 am
PM11:11am

https://wallstreet...0-takeover-target/

BE11:11am

PM11:11am

Random Wall St Wires...

11:12 am
BE11:12am

And congratulations to them, at least in part for being awake at 6am.

BE11:12am

But we can't compete with a rumour aggregation service.

BE11:12am

We have an editorial code of practice, which is here: https://aboutus.ft...ft-editorial-code/

11:12 am
BE11:12am

As a general rule of thumb, we require at least two independent sources for each story.

BE11:13am

That kind of thing.

BE11:13am

As well as a requirement to be mindful of EU Market Abuse Regulations, and of FSMA

11:13 am
BE11:13am

The internet's a big place, though.

BE11:13am

Bit enough for services that shortcut the whole niceity of sourcing and don't care much for EU Market Abuse Regulations, and of FSMA. Good luck to them.

BE11:13am

That's not us though. We can't play that game.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

It's a fun game! But we're not allowed to play it.

BE11:13am

Responsibility and all that junk.

BE11:14am

So anyway, Worldpay confirms.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

.... has received preliminary approaches from Vantiv and JP Morgan Chase Bank in relation to the potential acquisition

Worldpay Group PLC (WPG:LSE): Last: 387.90, up 68.4 (+21.41%), High: 403.00, Low: 326.80, Volume: 24.56m
BE11:14am

Looks extremely early in the process

11:14 am
BE11:15am

And the leak on the 4th July holiday is also worth noting

BE11:16am

One can speculate who's put on the back foot by this, but we won't go down that route.

BE11:16am

Instead, here's a whack of UBS to go through the valuations.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Vantiv had $1.9bn in sales in 2016, with $1.5bn coming from merchant services and the balance from issuer processing. It processed $920bn in volumes across 25bn transactions (21bn in merchant acquiring) in 2016. It ended March 2017 with net debt of $3.0bn giving it a leverage ratio of 3.3x trailing EBITDA. In 2014 Vantiv was ranked as the No 2 in global merchant acquiring per Nilson, behind Bank of America, while (JP Morgan) Chase Paymentech was No 4 with Worldpay No. 5 and First Data No. 3. Precedent activity and peer group valuations One of the largest recent transactions in the sector involved Global Payments acquiring Heartland Payments for $4.3bn in December 2015. At time of announcement that implied around 15.5x forward EBITDA (based on IBES consensus forward EBITDA at the time). As of today, Vantiv is trading at a 13.4x 2018E consensus EV/EBITDA, Global Payments at 14.3x, Paypal at 15.0x and Wirecard at 13.2x. The 2018E PERs are 17.1x, 19.7x and 25.0x respectively. At 366p Worldpay currently trades on 14x EV/EBITDA '18E and 23x P/E. As a sensitivity, at our previously published upside scenario of 430p, Worldpay would trade on 16.2x ‘18E EV/EBITDA.

BE11:18am

(@Scalper: agreed, though there's an even greater quantity of M&A bulls*** around. Reporting both with equal weight doesn't do much to maintain an orderly or honest market.)

BE11:18am

In terms of the sector ............

11:18 am
Paysafe Group PLC (PAYS:LSE): Last: 516.00, up 10.5 (+2.08%), High: 524.00, Low: 505.00, Volume: 2.02m

PM11:19am

Wirecard

PM11:19am

11:19 am
PM11:20am

PM11:20am

But back to Worldpay

PM11:20am

11:20 am
PM11:20am

Since float

BE11:21am

.. though has come off a bit due to concerns about the UK consumer and Brexit effect

11:21 am
BE11:21am

UK is ~39% and ~42% of Worldpay’s
revenue and EBITDA, respectively, according to Citi

BE11:23am

That's the WPUK merchant business. Don't have figures for Global eCom
to hand, but see yesterday's stuff about the indebted UK consumer. Same deal, pretty much,

BE11:23am

Anyway, worth noting also it's the second bid in the sector after Nets.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Nets being Danish

PM11:25am

Heres Lex on Nets https://www.ft.com...-91a7-502f7ee26895

BE11:25am

And of course the rumours around the Swiss company we won't name, which isn't precisely the same sector but moves in similar spheres.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Anyway, wires chucking up stuff now about Google, Amazon, and Apple being potential counterbidders.

PM11:26am

Really?

BE11:26am

Yeah, quoting the likes of United First Partners.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Censored

BE11:27am

Anyway, that's all I can think of sating about that right now. Let's move on.

undefined

Q1s from Sainsburys

http://www.investe...1707040700059996J/

PM11:27am

Reaction seems mildly positive

11:28 am
BE11:28am

They're okay numbers, but Q1 doesn't really matter much.

BE11:28am

Increasingly less, in fact, due to Argos being the kicker in the Sainsbury story, and Argos is very very seasonal.

BE11:29am

Weather's been a help.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

As has inflation for the food side.

BE11:30am

There's also the year's late Mother's Day and Easter, which apparently wasn't in everyone's forecasts

BE11:30am

....... suggesting analysts don't have calendars. But whatever.

11:30 am

No mention of the new software in their self-checkout tills taht ive seen

PM11:31am

It's problematic

PM11:31am

New interface

11:31 am
PM11:31am

V v confusing -- and slow to override by staff

PM11:32am

At our Sainsburys local the queue length has doubled

BE11:32am

Hm. Your struggles with newfangled technology seem to be developing into a theme.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Can't say I've noticed, FWIW.

PM11:32am

It's a fact Bryce. I will do you a video

BE11:32am

No ta!

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Have Barclays on Sainsbury, to say the figures are fine.

PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets LIve

BE11:33am

· Groceries online achieved 8% sales growth (7% in 4Q) and convenience saw 10% sales growth (vs nearly 7% in 4Q).

· Sainsbury’s Bank increased its active customer base by 6% yoy.

· There is no comment on profit, but this is not surprising given it is the first quarter of the year.

· Sainsbury states it is on track to achieve £145m of cost savings this year and states it remains confident delivery £160m of EBITDA synergies from the Argos transaction.

· CONCLUSION: The overall sales figure appears moderately better than expected, despite slightly weak recent market share data. This, combined with apparent resilience at Argos, should be taken positively in our opinion.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Valuation

Sainsbury is on a 2018 P/E of 12.1x vs Morrison 19.0x (European sector average of 14.1x).

BE11:33am

And Jefferies.

BE11:34am

A Q1 beat... with Q1 group retail LFL of 2.3% (2% ex the impact of Easter timing) compared with JEFe of 1.6% and consensus of 1.9%. Today's call confirmed mgmt comfort with market expectations for FY 17/18 PBT of £571m, which implies group EBIT margin of -20bps (and by extension margin stability in the core supermarket division given the first time consolidation of Argos' seasonally loss-making H1). We remain more cautious on £536m.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

...given a pop in food sales... which increased by a total of 3% in Q1, a major sequential improvement on 0.3% in Q4 last year. Easter timing flatters the magnitude of the inflection. SBRY mgmt refuted weather as a meaningful help in Q1, while recognising a further build in industry food inflation in recent months (with SBRY lagging the price rises pushed through the market in general). We remain unsure as to whether JS' food recovery is indicative of a wider industry trend (the obvious conclusion from recent Kantar updates) or whether it reflects marked, company specific progress. Today's call outlined market share gains for JS in produce, but also declines in overall food.

BE11:35am

...and gm showing some signs of weakness. Total growth in clothing sales continues to impress at +7.2% in Q1, but gm trends weakened with total growth of 1% now well below the 3.7% peak of Q3 16/17 (and 1.5% in Q4). An acceleration in Argos closures has contributed to this. Still, the combination of a record low UK savings ratio, now falling real disposable incomes and the increasing possibility of rate rises makes for a challenging outlook.

BE11:35am

Undemanding valuation, reflecting high forecast risks as the equity is currently
trading (on our sub consensus estimates) on a cal 2018 P/E and FCY of 13.8x and 5.6% respectively. A successful acquisition of Nisa could provide Sainsbury with an added buffer on food gross margins. This would be especially helpful if accompanied by an enlarged supplier agreement with McColl's (MCLS LN, NC, 200p). Nevertheless, we remain concerned by the ongoing lag in the core food business, as well as the significant disruption that a more downbeat UK consumer could represent for Argos.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

That's James Grzinic, and that'll do I think.

Virgin Money Holdings (UK) PLC (VM.:LSE): Last: 275.30, up 4.9 (+1.81%), High: 275.30, Low: 267.90, Volume: 431.79k
11:37 am
BE11:38am

So, the PRA review on consumer credit lending has said nearly nothing.

BE11:38am

EIR assumptions not capped,

PM11:39am

It's here https://www.fca.or...ormance-management

11:38 am
BE11:39am

Banks need to note in passing that consumers getting unsecured loans won't be able to pay them back, most likely, but other than that all is okay.

BE11:39am

Motor financing rules are basically unchanged.

BE11:39am

I'll let RBC summarise, as they're better at it.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

1. For 0% interest card offers, firms should be able to justify the assumptions and time periods used for forecasting the NPV of new
business, especially where maturity experience is limited for longer-term offers. Firms should have an appropriate risk framework to manage
the potential volatility in the portion of NII relating to 0% offers. This has been the largest issue for VM shareholders recently over concerns that
their 7% EIR rate is too high (compared to BARC and LLOY at 5%). If VM just has to justify its assumptions (rather than a hard cap put in place
by the PRA) then we view this positively relative to expectations - VM gives by far the most disclosure and justifications of any bank on its
EIR assumptions.

BE11:40am

2. A borrower's total debt, including secured debt, should be taken into account in the underwriting process. Most firms currently use only
credit scoring to approve unsecured loans - although most credit scores do already incorporate a measure of the consumer's total indebtedness
already. This change in explicit approach makes sense in our view and was always the most likely outcome from the review. We expect this will
curtail some growth in the consumer credit market going forward but as total household leverage has only recently bottomed and
expectations are for consumer credit to slowdown and high inflation to erode real debt, we expect this is already embedded in market
expectations.

BE11:40am

3. For motor finance, guaranteed future values should be set in a prudent manner compared with the expected future value of the car to
mitigate losses in a fall in used car prices. Lenders should assess the ability of motor finance books to withstand a significant decline in used
car prices and the PRA will require firms to assess the impact in 10% increments of declines in car prices. LLOY has the largest exposure to motor
finance and is the largest motor finance lender in the UK market. Currently, LLOY has a prudent GFV policy and makes £400-500 per car at the
end of lease periods. It should also be noted that historically declines in used car prices have been temporary and given the 3-4 year average
duration of PCP finance and leases, such scenarios could likely have relatively limited impact. We expect little change in policy from LLOY on the
motor finance book.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

4. For unsecured personal loans, firms should provide evidence of how their underwriting assessment and pricing of long-tenor or higher-
amount loans takes into account consumers’ motivation for borrowing and borrowers’ overall indebtedness. LLOY offers the largest
unsecured personal loans up to £50k but the industry average is £20-30k - beyond this average LLOY (and other banks) charge much higher
interest rates. Most banks offer tenors of up to 7 years but typically banks charge much higher interest rates for these loans. Loans of longer
tenor and larger size often require further investigation. One could argue therefore that banks are already assessing higher value and longer
tenor loans with more scrutiny. We would note that this is the slowest growing area of consumer finance and therefore has relatively
minimal impact anyway.

BE11:40am

Otherwise, it's all a bit wishy washy.

BE11:41am

Credit scoring must factor in that we're currently in extraordinary times, rates wise, and won't stay there forever.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

(Surely to hell that happens already, right?)

PM11:41am

(you'd have hoped so)

BE11:42am

Loss-leaders like 0% offers have to be monitored closely and explicitly reported.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

(Ditto? Surely?)

BE11:43am

There's stuff about prudent underwriting and risk appetite but nothing much that might stop companies feeding the monster.

BE11:43am

Which is ...... good ..... news. Apparently.

11:43 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 207.35, up 0.3 (+0.14%), High: 207.70, Low: 205.35, Volume: 6.38m
Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 2,332, down 36 (-1.52%), High: 2,374, Low: 2,332, Volume: 145.77k
BE11:44am

Etc.

11:43 am
undefined
BE11:45am

Rather further up the banking world from Virgin is HSBC.

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 724.00, down 5.8 (-0.79%), High: 726.70, Low: 721.10, Volume: 7.24m
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Where Berenberg is suggesting you take profit

BE11:45am

Shares are at or near a record high, I think, largely on the normalisation=divis idea.

PM11:46am

What was the suggested figure? $45bn or something cited by Morgan Stanley??

11:46 am
PM11:46am

$45bn in excess capital

BE11:47am

Yeah, that was last week, and will be somewhere in the archive. Berenberg's argument is that it's all in the price already.

BE11:47am

HSBC is one of our long-term winners in the sector. However, everything
has a price and considering its market-implied cost of equity of 7%,
assuming $13bn of annual capital return in perpetuity, we believe HSBC is
fully valued and downgrade to Hold.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Still a long-term winner: HSBC is on our long-term winner list due to two
main factors. Firstly, its focus on risk and return, and secondly, its focus on
cutting costs in absolute terms. We see these two traits enabling HSBC to
continue delivering sustainable capital return. As the current cycle comes
to an end with central banks talking up rates and removing liquidity from
the system, HSBC should be able to differentiate itself from its peers due to
these two traits.

BE11:47am

Risk/return focus: It has been difficult for HSBC to demonstrate its risk
and return focus in a world where central banks have suppressed risk
pricing for so long. We seem close to the point of change, with spreads
across the system so low and central banks seemingly intent on raising
rates and pulling liquidity from the system. Many in the market have seen
the weaker-than-expected revenue growth as a concern for HSBC, but we
see this as more of a reflection of the risk focus within the business.

BE11:48am

Cost delivery continues: The second reason HSBC is on our winner list has
been its focus on cutting costs in absolute terms. Many investors doubt its
ability to deliver on this, seeing HSBC as too big to manage. HSBC targets
an end-2017 exit run rate for quarterly costs of $6.9bn, which compares to
$7.2bn in Q1 2017 and consensus 2018 cost forecasts of $28.5bn.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

100% capital return is a good policy: In a world of little growth, paying out
100% of profits is the right route for a bank to follow. Ultimately, if there is
no ability to redeploy that capital to deliver a 10% return, we believe that
banks should return all their profits. Firstly, it stops management being
tempted to use that capital for something value destructive and secondly, it
demonstrates that regulators are confident about that bank’s capital
structure and hence balance sheet values. Following the US stress tests, we
now include $3bn pa of buybacks in our forecasts but still expect HSBC to
continue to increase its CET1 ratio of 14.3% at Q1 2017.

BE11:48am

Implied cost of equity of 7% too low: If we assume HSBC’s dividend
remains at the current level in perpetuity, and HSBC undertakes $3bn of buybacks pa, this would equate to c$13bn of capital return pa. This is
equivalent to over 90% of our 2019 net profit forecasts. If we assume zero
growth in this capital return, which seems fair considering where we are in
the long-term financial cycle, the market-implied cost of equity for HSBC is 7%. For us, this is too low, despite HSBC being a long-term winner.

BE11:48am

EPS changes reflect a number of factors: We now include a number of
one-offs in our forecasts, reflecting restructuring costs and litigation. We
also forecast revenue growth of 2% pa and flat costs, delivering positive
leverage.

11:48 am
PM11:48am

We should also mention this story pointed out by David earlier...

PM11:49am

https://www.bloomb...-first-outside-ceo

PM11:49am

HSBC Holdings Plc has approached Peter Hancock, the former boss of American International Group Inc., to be its next chief executive officer as incoming Chairman Mark Tucker considers internal and external candidates to lead Europe’s largest bank,

11:49 am
PM11:49am

Stuart Gulliver retires next year

BE11:50am

Hm. The day of the US stress tests, I think we grumped a bit about HSBC returning excess cash less than a decade after the head of the crisis.

BE11:52am

Then, later in the day, Levine was very good on the theme. (As is usual.) He pointed out that banks are supposed to make money and return it to shareholders. That's a normalisation. And it should be perfectly normal for a bank with a £141bn market cap to return about $13bn a year.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Anyway, that's HSBC.

undefined
BE11:53am

Morning @Arash, haven't had time to get my head around Clariant/Huntsman.

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Arash is referring to this i think https://www.bloomb...tivist-fund-corvex

PM11:53am

Activist hedge fund Corvex Management has built a stake in Clariant AG in a move designed to undo the Swiss chemicals maker’s $6.4 billion planned takeover of Huntsman Corp., according to people with knowledge of the situation.

Corvex, which has built a stake in Clariant that exceeds the disclosure threshold of 3 percent, plans to push the company to explore alternatives to the deal including a potential sale, said the people, who asked not to be named because the situation is private.

The activist investor believes the Huntsman acquisition, which was championed by Clariant Chief Executive Officer Hariolf Kottmann, lacks strategic rationale, the people said.

PM11:54am

The guy running Corvex is Keith Meister, who used to work with Icahn

11:55 am
PM11:55am

Activism all the rage in Switzerland all of a sudden

undefined
BE11:55am

Mildly interesting flashes crossing the tape.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

*LEAHY EXPECTS AMAZON TO MAKE GROCERY ACQUISITION IN EUROPE

BE11:56am

I say "mildly interesting" because I think everyone expects that, though it's still worth noting that Leahy agrees.

BE11:57am

It's also a convenient excuse to recap this HSBC note from late yesterday, arguing that Tesco's a more plausible target for Amazon than Ocado.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Yes, Tesco. For Amazon.

BE11:59am

The note's co-authored by David McCarthy, who I suspect has spent so long looking at Tesco he's now going into the deep subtext, like a graduate picking up buried themes in The Waste Land that Eliot didn't even know about.

BE11:59am

Here's the gist of it anyway.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Amazon’s purchase of Whole Foods in the US suggests several things to us, none of which looks good for Ocado. First, Amazon (AMZN US, USD968, not rated) seems to be leaning towards omni-channel (Ocado is single channel), it suggests that local C&C or local picking points are the future (Ocado operates central picking), and that building a fresh food supply chain is expensive and difficult (Ocado still relies heavily on Waitrose). We believe Amazon’s move suggests Ocado is less likely to be a potential acquisition target for Amazon and that Tesco (TSCO LN, 169p, Buy) might be considered.

BE12:00pm

Grocery Home Delivery (GHD) growth has slowed significantly as some retailers have pulled back from growing their online operations at the expense of store sales. This is not a surprise to us, and we believe that GHD had been driven by retailers increasingly subsidising delivery (eg lower delivery costs, lower minimum basket sizes, coupons and vouchers, etc). Most UK consumers do not use GHD and of those that do, most use it infrequently and do so because it is highly subsidised. The GHD market has grown much less than the discount market, suggesting that consumers want lower prices more than GHD, which remains a niche business with c7% of the total market and only half the size of the two discounters combined. Ocado operates in a growing market but as market growth slows and the overall food market gets more competitive, it might find growth harder to come by.

BE12:01pm

Ocado’s challenges: Two key determinants of online profitability are drop density and average basket size. Ocado’s annual sales last year were cGBP1.3bn, meaning that drop densities remain low, and considerably lower than Tesco’s, the UK market leader in online. Meanwhile, Ocado’s average basket size continues to be eroded.

12:01 pm
PM12:02pm

Poor Ocado

BE12:02pm

While it's a mug's game to make predictions, I'll rate Amazon-Tesco an outside bet.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 290.80, up 1.6 (+0.55%), High: 291.60, Low: 283.00, Volume: 494.44k

12:10 pm
PM12:10pm

Closing now

BE11:32am

The +2.3% combined group retail LFL includes a 0.3ppt benefit from the timing shift of Easter/Mother’s Day – but this should have been incorporated in forecasts. (This is the reversal of a -0.6ppt headwind in 4Q, but this is spread over 16 weeks in 1Q compared with 9 weeks in 4Q.)

· Although Sainsbury no longer discloses a separate Argos LFL sales figure, there is evidence to suggest that Argos’s LFL sales have not slowed materially since 4Q (when its LFL was +4.3%). Sainsbury states that total GM sales (for both banners) slowed only from +1.5% in 4Q to +1.0% in 1Q (see table below), despite Argos concession closures in Homebase having accelerated this quarter.

· Total grocery sales moved from +0.3% in 4Q to +3.0% in 1Q, GM went from +1.5% to +1.0% and Clothing from +5.2% to +7.2%.
